author: flameshana9

text:
Did you notice if Dragon Quest VIII is based on Knight & Baby/Guardian's Crusade for its game world environment?

For anyone don't know about Knight & Baby/Guardian's Crusade:
Knight & Baby, or called "Guardian's Crusade" in US version, is a PS1 JRPG that its world isn't symbolized with icons or 3D icons for any places in world map such as towns, dungeon entrances, house, etc like traditional JRPG. Instead, all of them are directly rendered. So, you can see any details of any towns without entering it. 

Proofs if DQVIII is based on Knight & Baby/Guardian's Crusade are:
-Anything at world map is completely not symbolized by any icons.
-Music changes if you enter the town, except for loading screen and people appears after loading screen. K&B/GC have no loading screen when entering any towns and any people at any towns are visible even the town isn't entered.
-You can only land at outside of any towns, except for auto landing positioning when you want to land at inside of any towns.
-Visible enemies, only for 3DS version of DQVIII.
-Ship can only parked at specified place. For DQVIII, you can only park ship at the port.

text: I have an interesting love-hate relationship with this game. I love the beautiful cel-shaded graphics, I love the characters, I love the British voice acting and the world as a whole. But in this game the random encounters annoy me way more than in any other RPG. The dungeons and the distances in the world map are so long that you are going to hear that same battle theme loop over and over and over again. Not to mention that you can only save in towns, so if you die, you go all the way back. This is possibly the single hardest J-RPG I've ever played and not for the right reason. I still love this game, but I've never finished this and having spent over 100 hours with this, I have decided not to come back and finish this at any time.

text: @CaptainThunderWolfÂ 9 = IX...
author: Nifty

text:
@NiftyÂ That would be exactly what I said, yes. The Roman system goes, at specific intervals, an I is placed before a multiple of five to denote being less than that interval of 5.

I = 1

II = 2

III = 3

IV = 4

V = 5

VIII = 8

X = 10

IX = 9

author: Hanai

text:
Whatever, I am honestly pretty amazed that anyone would even bother to make an issue about something as trivial as this.
My comment was supposed to make the point "it sounds as beautiful as something from Mozart", not start a discussion whether it is "similar enough" to Mozart or not
Give it a rest, seriously.
author: Laurelindo

text: And I'm saying it doesn't sound remotely like it could have come from Mozart, in terms of quality or style.
author: CoJaPo100

text:
Ok, now I get that.
I feel there's a difference between an actual comparison and an hyperbole, but I actually overreacted.
author: VladNorris

text: I mean, you might as well hear someone saying "this song is like heaven!" and then answer that there is no proof that heaven really feels like this - that would be almost the same kind of reaction, IMO.
author: Laurelindo

text:
And not even that is true.
It seems you haven't listened to actual classical music, because how an orchestra sounds today nas nothing to with how people composed back then.
I can see how that's a way to show respect and praise with this piece(which I find beatiful as well), but this was pretty much...pretentious.

Orchestral music =/= Classical music.
author: VladNorris

text:
I don't know why it matters that I mentioned Mozart, it should be obvious what point I was trying to make, so i find it unnecessary to get so hung up over that.
Most people would interpret my comment as "oh, he thinks this sounds like something that might have come from artists like Mozart, and that it has the same kind of classical feel as the music from his time period".
author: Laurelindo

text:
You still gave the wtong impression and i'm uncertain you know enough about musical composition to tell such.
"Just because Mozart had a certain style it doesn't mean he would not be able to use other styles"
It actually does. The style you have as a composer isn't defined by the genre, is defined by personal traits and preferences. Let alone Mozart had such musical inequiparable talent due him being autist, and that I find Uematsu kinda overrated(not saying bad, but overrated).
author: VladNorris

text:
I didn't say this sounded exactly the same as Mozart's own works, I said it sounded like something he would have been capable of writing and that it held the same level of quality as his own works.
Just because Mozart had a certain style it doesn't mean he would not be able to use other styles - look at Nobuo Uematsu for example, I consider him just as talented as Mozart and he has written all kinds of songs for the Final Fantasy series, even though he gravitates towards classical music.
author: Laurelindo

text: I was saying that this sounds like something that could have very likely come from Mozart and that it had the same level of quality as his works, not that it sounded exactly like his own compositions.
author: Laurelindo

text: Everyone gets what Laurelindo is saying.  I think that's what matters, but it is amazing how everyone who plays games knows such a variety of things.  Until you said so- I would never had known that about Mozart :)
author: P Helm

text: Took the words right out of my mouth. I kind of suspect that the guy you're replying to has never listened to Mozart and uses his name as a catch-all term for anything orchestral.
author: CoJaPo100

text:
This isn't like Mozart's style.
AT ALL.
Mozart's style was more frantic.
I know what you're trying to say but...no.
At least the allegory is wrong.

*Sits on his chair and stretches his whole body*

text:
im so glad I grew up playing RPG games like this one.
you have no limit to what you can do in an RPG world like this one for instance.
but these days kids are being brainwashed with th CoD crap. I too am a victim of modern day gaming like this, I really do love shooting games as well, but this game, Dragon Quest VIII, is the first game I have ever played and I still love it to this day. If only there was a world like the world of DQVIII. BEST GAME EVER. ALONG WITH EARTHBOUND AND MOTHER!!!!!!!!

author: blindedby2monkeys

text: @MyHumanLife (continued). As much as I love modern RPG's, and as much that I love that they've diversified and have developed deep stories and different types of settings, going back and playing DQ8 makes me remember why I fell in love with RPG's in the first place. It's just a simple fantasy setting, yourself as the hero, out to save the day from a bad guy, with fantastic music and stylized graphics. No complicated moral issues or demigods or "grittiness", just straight-forward, rpg goodness =)
author: MyHumanLife

text: I adore Dragon Quest VIII. There are lots and lots of great RPG's out there, but one of the things that makes me love DQ8 so much is its simplicity. Not that it's easy, but it isn't overcomplicated in the story or in the game's mechanic's, it's very straight forward. This gives it a nice nostalgic feeling to it, especially if you grew up playing 16-bit era rpgs. It gives me the same "feeling" games like FFIV and Lufia gave me back in the day. And the music is amazing ;)
author: MyHumanLife

text:
I am actually a tough dude, I rarely weep for anything, but this game makes me cry like a little baby. I mean, this music... you just want to strand around without the opression of anything. I equipped the special ring and no more fights. Just bathe your soul in the warmth of the restless sun, quench your sadness to the caotic twinker of spotless clouds, feel the smooth touch of the cloth on the colapsed skin your journeys have given to the Earth cyclic chaos and... breath in the air.
Love it!

Precisely my thoughts on this matter, it' just slightly nostalgic since I've known the series from the first one [1992]...

Could be just another shooter with a half decent series' name though - we'll have to see...
author: Sieur Mordred

text:
Those are some great titles to look forward to - especially Bioshock 2 [the first one was great] and Assassin's Creed 2 [personally], Red Dead Redemption also has a lot of potential...

I am also looking forward to Project Trico "Shadow of Colossus 2" and Thief 4 [The Thief games were made by the same people who developed Bioshock]...

And who could miss a classic like Wolfenstein...
author: Sieur Mordred

text:
Most certainly I am, though I tend to an overall eclectic person in the sense that I pretty much go for any game genre as long as it's good...

I'm currently looking forward to:

Dragon Age

Final Fantasy XIII

Alan Wake

Mass Effect 2 [2010]

Diablo 3

How about you, any titles that particularly catch your eye this year?
author: Sieur Mordred

text:
Yes, I played some of the earlier games in the Dragon Quest as well as this one - the first seven games were pretty retro, with pretty old graphics, like in the original Zelda...

I liked this game the best, for reasons like: it's a complete open world, with massive landscapes to explore in full 3D, and Final Fantasy like battles - along the lines of a classic story...

i Would say that I prefer it to Final Fantasy, and it's worth renting if your not sure...
author: Sieur Mordred

text: I mean it sounds like an old 1950's Disney epic film as well as sounding great and original...
author: Sieur Mordred

text:
Hey, same here!

It's a great piece of music - deserving of a major film soundtrack...

Then again, it's right out of the 50's...

text:
Aside from Dragon Warrior 8, what exceptional games has SE made since their merge?

As far as I can tell, there was this, and then...well that's about it

FFXI and FFXII were mediocre at best, terrible at worst. Valkyrie Profile 2 was decent, but Enix did a better job with the first one, much like Star Ocean 3, Star Ocean 2 was far far better. Infinite Undiscovery and Last Remnant are totally forgettable

Seriously, what game/franchise they've developed since, has been better than before?
